TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit BuildProperty extends System.Object

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Diagnostics.DebuggerDisplay("BuildProperty (Name = { Name }, Value = { Value }, FinalValue = { FinalValue }, Condition = { Condition })")

Docs.summary: This class holds an MSBuild property. This may be a property that is represented in the MSBuild project file by an XML element, or it may not be represented in any real XML file (e.g., global properties, environment properties, etc.)

remarks.format:
## Examples The following example creates a <xref:Microsoft.Build.BuildEngine.Project> object and uses the <xref:Microsoft.Build.BuildEngine.Project.LoadXml%2A> method to add content to the project. The <xref:Microsoft.Build.BuildEngine.BuildProperty>, <xref:Microsoft.Build.BuildEngine.BuildPropertyGroup>, and <xref:Microsoft.Build.BuildEngine.BuildPropertyGroupCollection> classes are used to add, remove, and change items in the project.
[!code-csharp[msbuild_AddNewProperty#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Misc/msbuild_AddNewProperty/CS/Program.cs#1)] [!code-vb[msbuild_AddNewProperty#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Misc/msbuild_AddNewProperty/VB/Module1.vb#1)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(string propertyName, string propertyValue) cil managed
Public Sub New (propertyName As String, propertyValue As String)

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Runtime.TargetedPatchingOptOut("Performance critical to inline this type of method across NGen image boundaries")

Docs.summary: Constructor, which initializes the property from just the property name and value, creating it as a "normal" property. This ends up creating a new XML element for the property under a dummy XML document.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance class Microsoft.Build.BuildEngine.BuildProperty Clone(bool deepClone) cil managed
Public Function Clone (deepClone As Boolean) As BuildProperty

Docs.summary:
Creates a shallow or deep clone of this BuildProperty object.
A shallow clone points at the same XML element as the original, so that modifications to the name or value will be reflected in both copies. However, the two copies could have different a finalValue.
A deep clone actually clones the XML element as well, so that the two copies are completely independent of each other.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A shallow copy of a <xref:Microsoft.Build.BuildEngine.BuildProperty> references the same XML element as the original. Modifications to the name or value of a shallow copy will be reflected in both copies. However, depending on property evaluation, the two copies could have different <xref:Microsoft.Build.BuildEngine.BuildProperty.FinalValue%2A> property values.
A deep copy of a <xref:Microsoft.Build.BuildEngine.BuildProperty> creates a new XML element to reference so that both copies of the <xref:Microsoft.Build.BuildEngine.BuildProperty> can be independently modified.

Docs.summary: Returns the unescaped value of the property.
Docs.value: The final value of the property after all property evaluations have been performed.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property IsImported As Boolean

Docs.summary: Did this property originate from an imported project file?
Docs.value: if the property was imported into the project; otherwise, .

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property Name As String
public: property System::String ^ Name { System::String ^ get(); };

Docs.summary: Accessor for the property name. This is read-only, so one cannot change the property name once it's set ... your only option is to create a new BuildProperty object. The reason is that BuildProperty objects are often stored in hash tables where the hash function is based on the property name. Modifying the property name of an existing BuildProperty object would make the hash table incorrect.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following example creates a <xref:Microsoft.Build.BuildEngine.Project> object and uses the <xref:Microsoft.Build.BuildEngine.Project.LoadXml%2A> method to add content to the project. The <xref:Microsoft.Build.BuildEngine.BuildProperty>, <xref:Microsoft.Build.BuildEngine.BuildPropertyGroup>, and <xref:Microsoft.Build.BuildEngine.BuildPropertyGroupCollection> classes are used to add, remove, and change items in the project.

remarks.format: The equivalent method for this operator is <xref:Microsoft.Build.BuildEngine.BuildProperty.ToString?displayProperty=nameWithType>
